title: Leicester City 2-1 Burnley: Foxes see off stubborn Burnley with tributes paid to Khun Vichai
text:
Youri Tielemans briefly sent Leicester second in the Premier League on the day they came to remember the man who helped make their dreams come true.

Eight days from the first anniversary of the death of owner Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha, who was killed in a helicopter crash near the King Power Stadium on October 27, Leicester fought back from a goal down against Burnley to leapfrog Manchester City in the table for at least a few hours – with a helping hand from VAR.

The visitors took a 26th-minute lead through Chris Wood, but Jamie Vardy equalised in first-half stoppage time – an eloquent response to the Burnley fans who had been taunting him about the spat between his wife, Rebekah, and Colleen Rooney.

Leicester midfielder Youri Tielemans gave his side the lead in the second half against Burnley

Tielemans celebrates in front of the home fans after scoring the decisive goal on Saturday

MATCH FACTS AND LEAGUE TABLE Leicester City (4-1-4-1) : Schmeichel; Chilwell, Soyuncu, Evans, Pereira; Ndidi; Barnes (Morgan 79), Maddison (Praet 73), Tielemans, Perez (Gray 67); Vardy Subs not used: Albrighton, Choudhury, Justin, Ward Booked: Goals: Vardy (45), Tielemans (74) Manager: Brendan Rodgers Burnley (4-4-2): Pope; Lowton, Tarkowski, Mee, Pieters; Brady (Lennon 65), Hendrick, Westwood, McNeil; Wood, Rodriguez (Vydra 83) Subs not used: Bardsley, Gibson, Hart, Long, Taylor Booked: Hendrick, Wood, Lowton Goals: Wood (26) Manager: Sean Dyche Referee: Jon Moss Stadium King Power Stadium Season at a glance Live tables

Tielemans struck the winner in the 74th minute, not long before Burnley believed they had levelled it with Jonny Evans’ own-goal – only for VAR to indicate a foul by Wood on the centre-back.

Vichai was the man in charge when Leicester won the title in 2016, and under the control of his son, Aiyawatt, Leicester are making it another season to remember.

Without the influential Ashley Barnes due to a groin injury, Burnley nonetheless matched Leicester in the first half.

The home side looked unusually shaky at the back, with Ricardo Pereira and Caglar Soyuncu particularly imprecise. In the 16th minute, Ashley Westwood’s shot from the edge of the penalty area deflected off both of them, with Wood just unable to make solid contact to divert the ball past Kasper Schmeichel.

Jamie Vardy equalised for Leicester just before half time with a bullet header beyond Tom Pope

Vardy leaps in jubilation after bringing his side back into the contest at the King Power stadium

The Leicester striker dedicates his goal to the club's late chairman Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha

Two minutes later, Soyuncu escaped his markers but headed James Maddison’s corner just wide. This was Maddison’s first appearance since he was pictured in a casino during England’s defeat by Czech Republic, after illness had forced him out of the squad.

Leicester came close again soon afterwards when the impressive Tielemans sent Pereira clear down the right. Harvey Barnes was first to the cross only for Matt Lowton to block it, and Ben Mee hooked the follow-up from Maddison off the line.

Lowton’s intervention proved crucial as Burnley swiftly took the lead, once more exposing Leicester’s fragility in defence. Dwight McNeil sent over an insidious cross from the right and Wood leapt above both Soyuncu and Jonny Evans to power the ball past Schmeichel.

Chris Wood gave the visitors the opener after guiding home a Dwight McNeil delivery

The New Zealander wheels away in delight after giving Burnley a surprise lead on Saturday

Burnley's Jay Rodriguez makes his way into the Leicester box as he is tracked by Jonny Evans

At this stage, Burnley’s plan was working perfectly. They defended deep to deny Vardy space, and also doubled up in wide areas to subdue Leicester’s attacking full-backs, Pereira and Ben Chilwell.

Westwood was busy and clever in central midfield, while Wood and Jay Rodriguez kept the Foxes defence honest with their physical strength and unselfish running.

Yet no team can relax when facing one of the Premier League’s most efficient goalscorers. Vardy had barely been in the game, but he showed how dangerous he can be when he raced on to Maddison’s lofted pass but fired into the side netting.

The next time a chance came, Vardy showed no mercy as outjumped Mee to head Barnes’ superb left-wing cross beyond Nick Pope. After being taunted by the visiting fans, Vardy celebrated with typical swagger by running towards them and lifting his hands to his ears. Wisely, he stopped his charge at the halfway line – but the forward had made his point.

Wood almost got his second of the game but failed to put the ball past Kasper Schmeichel

Khun Vichai died last year in a tragic helicopter accident outside the King Power stadium

It was one of the few times Leicester had reached the byline in the first half but they came out for the second half with greater purpose and created far more problems for Sean Dyche’s men.

Pereira had regained his rhythm and nearly set up Vardy for a second after Barnes had dummied a low cross, though Lowton read the danger and poked clear. Maddison swapped passes with Tielemans before blasting over from the edge of the penalty area.

Then, Ayoze Perez – who had a poor afternoon – squandered a glorious chance to give Leicester the lead. Vardy robbed Jeff Hendrick in midfield and fed the Spaniard, who released Pereira but skied the return pass. It was no surprised to see him replaced by Demarai Gray soon afterwards.

Leicester players wore warm up tops with their former owner's initials before kick off

Fans rose to their feet on the 60th minute to pay tribute to Khun Vichai on an emotional day

What a good substitution it proved, as Gray started to combine effectively with Pereira on the right, and their interplay led to the second goal.

A one-two gave Gray the space to cross, Barnes again sold the dummy to allow Tielemans, free inside the box, the time he needed to control the ball and smash it in off the crossbar. In the directors’ box, Aiyawatt, known as Khun Top, clenched his fist in celebration.

Leicester were dominant, so why did they switch off? Burnley grew in confidence and thought they had an equaliser when Lowton robbed Tielemans and crossed for Wood. Schmeichel saved the original effort, only for the ball to rebound off Evans and into the net.

Evans protested immediately, and his complaint was upheld by VAR, which ruled that Wood had tripped the Leicester defender as he tried to clear. Burnley were furious, and Lowton and Westwood continued the protests to the officials long after the whistle had blown.
description: TOM COLLOMOSSE AT THE KING POWER: Youri Tielemans latched onto a Demarai Gray cross to score the decisive goal to give Leicester all three points in the Premier League.
authors: Tom Collomosse For The Daily Mail
